helios

Class Validators

  • java.lang.Object
    • helios.Validators

  • public class Validators
extends java.lang.Object

    All basic validators implemented in Helios can be found here. Validators normally are used in Helios.validate(java.lang.String, T, helios.Validator<T>...) methods.

    Note
    		 Check Helios to see how to use validators
    Since:
    0.1.0
    See Also:
    Helios.validate(java.lang.String, T, helios.Validator<T>...)

    • Method Detail

      • required

        public static <T> Validator<T> required()

        Checks that a given value is present (is not null).

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.required;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class RequiredTest {

    @Test public void testRequired() {
        Long id = null;
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("id", id, required());

        assertEquals(errors.size(), 1);
        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "required");
    }
}
        Returns:
        a Validator to make sure a given value is present
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • min

        public static <T extends java.lang.Number> Validator<T> min(T min)

        Checks that a given Number number should be greater than the number passed as parameter.

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.min;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class MinNumberTest {

    @Test public void testMinNumber() {
        Integer numberToValidate = 4;
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("top", numberToValidate, min(5));

        assertEquals(errors.size(), 1);
        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "min.notmet");
    }
}
        Parameters:
        min - to check against
        Returns:
        a Validator instance
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • positive

        public static <T extends java.lang.Number> Validator<T> positive()

        Checks that a given Number is a positive number

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.positive;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class PositiveNumberTest {

    @Test public void testPositiveNumber() {
        Integer numberToValidate = -1;
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("number", numberToValidate, positive());

        assertEquals(errors.size(), 1);
        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "positive.notmet");
    }
}
        Returns:
        a Validator instance
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • minOfList

        public static Validator<java.util.List<?>> minOfList(int min)

        Checks that a given List size is greater than the number passed as parameter.

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.minOfList;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Arrays;
import org.junit.Test;

public class MinOfListTest {

    @Test public void testMinOfList() {
        List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1,2,3);
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("sample", numbers, minOfList(5));

        assertEquals(errors.size(), 1);
        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "list.min.notmet");
    }
}
        Parameters:
        min - minimum number of elements the list should have
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • maxOfList

        public static Validator<java.util.List<?>> maxOfList(int max)

        Checks that a given List size is less than the number passed as parameter.

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.maxOfList;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Arrays;
import org.junit.Test;

public class MaxOfListTest {

    @Test public void testMaxOfList() {
        List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1,2,3);
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("sample", numbers, maxOfList(2));

        assertEquals(errors.size(), 1);
        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "list.max.notmet");
    }
}
        Parameters:
        max - maximum number of elements the list should have
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • inRangeOfList

        public static Validator<java.util.List<?>> inRangeOfList(int min,
                                                         int max)

        Checks that a given List size is within a specific range given by two numbers passed as parameters.

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.inRangeOfList;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Arrays;
import org.junit.Test;

public class InRangeOfListTest {

    @Test public void testInRangeList() {
        List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1,2,3);

        List<ValidatorError> minErrors = validate("min", numbers, inRangeOfList(4,5));
        List<ValidatorError> maxErrors = validate("max", numbers, inRangeOfList(0,2));

        assertEquals(minErrors.get(0).key, "list.min.notmet");
        assertEquals(maxErrors.get(0).key, "list.max.notmet");
    }
}
        Parameters:
        min - minimum number of elements the list should have
        max - maximum number of elements the list should have
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • minOfString

        public static Validator<java.lang.String> minOfString(int min)

        Checks that a given String has a minimum number of characters.

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.minOfString;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class MinOfStringTest {

    @Test public void testMinOfString() {
        String name = "John";
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("name", name, minOfString(5));

        assertEquals(errors.size(), 1);
        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "string.min.notmet");
    }
}
        Parameters:
        min - minimum number of characters that the string should have
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • maxOfString

        public static Validator<java.lang.String> maxOfString(int max)

        Checks that a given String has a maximum number of characters.

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.maxOfString;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class MaxOfStringTest {

    @Test public void testMaxOfString() {
        String name = "John";
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("name", name, maxOfString(3));

        assertEquals(errors.size(), 1);
        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "string.max.notmet");
    }
}
        Parameters:
        max - maximum number of characters that the string should have
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • inRangeOfString

        public static Validator<java.lang.String> inRangeOfString(int min,
                                                          int max)

        Checks that a given String length is within a specific range given by two numbers passed as parameters.

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.inRangeOfString;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class InRangeOfStringTest {

    @Test public void testInRangeOfString() {
        String name = "airport";

        List<ValidatorError> minErrors = validate("strings", name, inRangeOfString(8,10));
        List<ValidatorError> maxErrors = validate("strings", name, inRangeOfString(0,3));

        assertEquals(minErrors.get(0).key, "string.min.notmet");
        assertEquals(maxErrors.get(0).key, "string.max.notmet");
    }
}
        Important
        		 InRangeOfString validator is composed by minOfString and maxOfString validators.
        Parameters:
        min - minimum number of characters the string should have
        max - maximum number of characters the string should have
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • max

        public static <T extends java.lang.Number> Validator<T> max(T max)

        Checks that a given Number is less than the number passed as parameter

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.max;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class MaxNumberTest {

    @Test public void testMaxNumber() {
        Integer numberToValidate = 10;
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("top", numberToValidate, max(5));

        assertEquals(errors.size(), 1);
        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "max.notmet");
    }
}
        Parameters:
        max - minimum number of characters that the string should have
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • inRange

        public static <T extends java.lang.Number> Validator<T> inRange(T min,
                                                                T max)

        Checks that a given Number is greater than a given min and also less than a given max

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.inRange;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class InRangeNumberTest {

    @Test public void testInRangeNumber() {
        Integer minFailingValue = 10;
        Integer maxFailingValue = 20;

        List<ValidatorError> minErrors = validate("min", minFailingValue, inRange(11,20));
        List<ValidatorError> maxErrors = validate("max", maxFailingValue, inRange(1,19));

        assertEquals(minErrors.get(0).key, "min.notmet");
        assertEquals(maxErrors.get(0).key, "max.notmet");
    }
}
        Important
        		 InRange validator is composed by min and max validators.
        Parameters:
        max - minimum number of characters that the string should have
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0

      • matches

        public static Validator<java.lang.String> matches(java.lang.String pattern)

        Checks that a given String matches a specific pattern

        Example usage
        package helios.samples.validators;

import static helios.Helios.validate;
import static helios.Validators.matches;

import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

import helios.ValidatorError;

import java.util.List;
import org.junit.Test;

public class MatchesTest {

    @Test public void testMatches() {
        String word = "airport";
        List<ValidatorError> errors = validate("word", word, matches("nono.*"));
        List<ValidatorError> noErrors = validate("word", word, matches("air.*"));

        assertEquals(errors.get(0).key, "matches");
        assertEquals(noErrors.size(), 0);
    }
}
        Parameters:
        pattern - the pattern the string should match
        Returns:
        a Validator
        Since:
        0.1.0
